page.title: 09STAYLEY HALL
page.content: { Stayley Hall}is a listed building of {architectural}and{historical interest.It is a rare example of late 16th century Pennine architecture and is the only large hall in Tameside.It is positioned on a spur overlooking the Tame valley and Millbrook.The hall was built on a mound which gives natural defence on two sides and it is possible that a moat was dug to protect the hall even before the {Norman Conquest.}Much of the building was rebuilt in the years following 1580,but the original Medieval manor house was built about 1340,and the middle section of the house still has timbers from the first building.When the house was rebuilt it was shaped in a letter "E",in honour of the reigning monarch{Queen Elizabeth I.}The hall is built of flat-stones and the roof is covered with gritstone slates or
